data.title: Jo Vermeulen
data.text:
I try to collect some resources here about research, writing and being an academic that I find useful.

Inspirational

"You and Your Research" by Richard Hamming.

Transcript of an inspirational talk in which Hamming discusses the atmosphere at Bell Labs where he worked with famous researchers like Claude Shannon and John Tukey. He discusses the different traits of researchers who do "great" work — such as courage, drive and commitment.

"Technology and Courage" by Ivan Sutherland.

Great article by one of the pioneers of human-computer interaction, computer graphics and virtual reality. Sutherland talks about the courage required to do creative, technical work.

"Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman!" by Richard P. Feynman.

One of the funniest and captivating books I ever read. Feynman's stories nicely illustrate one of the important traits of a good scientist: child-like curiosity. If you liked this one, also have a look at the follow-up book 'What Do You Care What Other People Think?'.

Richard Feynman - No Ordinary Genius.

Interesting BBC documentary from 1993 about Feynman's spirit and his scientific legacy.

"The Idea Factory: Learning to Think at MIT" by Pepper White.

Insightful book about the life of a grad student at MIT. It gives you a feeling of what it's like to study at a place like MIT. I was quite surprised to find out that the prologue of the book actually takes place in Belgium.

"The Last Lecture" by Randy Pausch.

Very inspiring and moving talk by the late Carnegie-Mellon University Professor Randy Pausch about really achieving your childhood dreams. Highly recommended, also for people outside of academia.

"In My Shoes" by César Hidalgo.

A self-recorded video series, showing the day-to-day life of a computer science professor at MIT. Features Hidalgo travelling to promote his Data USA visualization project, showing demos at the MIT Media Lab members event, and features other scholars such as Ben Shneiderman and Steven Pinker.

Genius Of Britain.

Interesting Channel 4 documentary about the history of the British science including amongst others the discoveries of Hooke, Newton, Watt, Faraday, Kelvin, Turing, Dirac and Watson. Narrated by contemporary British scientists such as Richard Dawkins, Stephen Hawking, David Attenborough, and James Dyson.

General Career Advice

"On Being A Scientist: Responsible Conduct in Research", National Academy Press

"How to do Research At the MIT AI Lab"

"How to Have a Bad Career in Research/Academia" by David A. Patterson

PLoS Computational Biology Ten Simple Rules Collection

Terence Tao's career advice page

What makes a good research question? by Amy J. Ko

Dealing with Rejection

"Dealing with Academic Rejection" by Eric Gilbert

"Dealing with Rejection" by Niklas Elmqvist

PhD

Some researchers have shared great bite size advice on how to approach a Ph.D. on Twitter:

a thread on a student's role in a research project and the notion of "ownership" by Yang Zhang

a thread on one thing most students need to unlearn by César A. Hidalgo

a thread on 10 practical tips for PhD students by Lucinda Doyle

a thread on tips for academic writing by Lucinda Doyle

Other websites, articles, and resources:

"Should I get a Ph.D.?"

Interesting collection of interviews about whether to get a Ph.D.

"Advice to (prospective) graduate students" by Vivek Haldar

"Advice for grad students", by Gene Golovchinsky

"The Art of Doing a PhD", by Jakob E. Bardram

Chapter 1 Club by Saul Greenberg

"So long, and thanks for the Ph.D.!" by Ronald T. Azuma

"The Ph.D. Grind" by Philip Guo

"A PhD Is Not Enough by Peter J. Feibelman

Grad Traps! by Daniel Silvermint

Presentation skills

"How to give a good research talk" by Simon Peyton Jones (video)

"How to Give a Great Research Talk", internal seminar at Microsoft Research with John Krumm, Patrick Baudisch, Mary Czerwinski and Rick Szeliski

Presentation Zen, a blog on presentation design with lots of useful tips

"Confessions of a Public Speaker", book on public speaking by Scott Berkun

Writing

"How to write a great research paper" by Simon Peyton Jones (video).

This is one of my favorite resources about paper writing. Covers both the writing process and how to structure a research paper.

"How to Get a Paper Accepted at OOPSLA" by Kent Beck.

Great advice on how to write a compelling abstract using four key sentences.

"Write good papers" by Daniel Lemire (article).

"Good Writing" by Marc H. Raibert.

"How do I write a good research paper?" by Amy J. Ko

"How can I become a good technical writer?" by Amy J. Ko

"An HCI research paper writing guide formatted as an HCI paper" by Jacob O. Wobbrock

"Error Codes for Paper Introductions" by Chris Parnin

Reviewing

"So You're a Program Committee Member Now: On Excellence in Reviews and Meta-Reviews and Championing Submitted Work That Has Merit" by Ken Hinckley.

"How to Review HCI/Visualization Papers" by Niklas Elmqvist

"How I review papers" by Dan Cosley

"Mistakes Reviewers Make" by Niklas Elmqvist

"Twelve tips for reviewers" by Henry L. Roediger III.

Provides several guidelines for reviewing, based on the book "Reviewing Scientific Works in Psychology".

"How NOT to review a paper. The tools and techniques of the adversarial reviewer" by Graham Cormode.

Laurian Vega's experiences as a CHI Work-in-Progress Meta-reviewer

Conferences

"Networking on the network" by Phil Agre.

"It Is Who You Know and Who Knows You" by Gary A. Olsen.

"The Shy Connector" by Sacha Chua.

"How to get the most out of conferences" by Scott Berkun.

Lots of practical tips about going to conferences, from shipping the printed proceedings back to your office to how to meet and socialize with many people.

"Conference Networking for Newbies", by Gilly Leshed.

Writing Rebuttals

"SIGCHI Rebuttals - Some suggestions to write them" by Albrecht Schmidt

"Writing CHI Rebuttals" by Gene Golovchinsky

"Reflections on Reviewing, Rebuttals and Respect" by Joe McCarthy

"Patterns for Writing Good Rebuttals" by Andreas Zeller

"Writing Rebuttals" by Niklas Elmqvist

"How to Write a ACM SIGCHI Rebuttal" by Hyunyoung Song

HCI-specific

"I give up on CHI/UIST" by James Landay

"Usability Evaluation Considered Harmful (Some of the Time)" by Saul Greenberg and Bill Buxton

"What makes a good HCI systems paper?" by Tessa Lau

"Why your [CHI] paper was rejected" by Antti Oulasvirta

"A Position on Peer Reviewing in HCI" by Jeffrey Bardzell (part 2, part 3)

"Seven Research Contribution Types in Human‐Computer Interaction" by Jacob O. Wobbrock
